title: Austro-Hungarian Navy
text:
The Austro-Hungarian Navy or Imperial and Royal War Navy (, in short k.u.k. Kriegsmarine, ) was the <a href="navy">naval force</a> of <a href="Austria-Hungary">Austria-Hungary</a>. Ships of the Austro-Hungarian Navy were designated "SMS", for "<a href="Seiner%20Majest%C3%A4t%20Schiff">Seiner Majestät Schiff</a>" (His Majesty's Ship). The k.u.k. Kriegsmarine came into being after the formation of Austria-Hungary in 1867, and ceased to exist in 1918 upon the Empire's defeat and subsequent collapse at the end of <a href="World%20War%20I">World War I</a>.
Prior to 1867, the Imperial Austrian Navy or simply the Austrian Navy. It saw action in the <a href="French%20Revolutionary%20Wars">French Revolutionary Wars</a>, the <a href="Napoleonic%20Wars">Napoleonic Wars</a>, the <a href="Second%20Egyptian%E2%80%93Ottoman%20War">Second Egyptian–Ottoman War</a>, the <a href="First%20Italian%20War%20of%20Independence">First</a> and <a href="Second%20Italian%20War%20of%20Independence">Second</a> <a href="Italian%20unification">Wars of Italian Independence</a>, the <a href="Second%20Schleswig%20War">Second Schleswig War</a>, and the <a href="Third%20War%20of%20Italian%20Independence">Third War of Italian Independence</a>. Following Austria's defeat by Prussia and Italy during the <a href="Seven%20Weeks%27%20War">Seven Weeks' War</a>, the Austrian Empire <a href="Austro-Hungarian%20Compromise%20of%201867">reformed itself into the dual monarchy</a> of Austria-Hungary, and the navy also became the Austro-Hungarian Navy. Largely neglected by the Empire in its early years, the k.u.k. Kriegsmarine expanded along with Austro-Hungarian industrialization into one of the largest navies in the <a href="Adriatic">Adriatic</a> and <a href="Mediterranean">Mediterranean</a> Seas. By 1914, the k.u.k. Kriegsmarine had a peacetime strength of 20,000 personnel, seeing action in the <a href="Boxer%20Rebellion">Boxer Rebellion</a> and other conflicts prior to World War I.
During most of <a href="World%20War%20I">World War I</a>, the Allied Powers maintained the <a href="Otranto%20Barrage">Otranto Barrage</a> to bottle up the k.u.k. Kriegsmarine in the Adriatic Sea. Largely tasked with defending the Empire's of coastline and of island seaboard, the Navy chose to rely on its <a href="List%20of%20Austro-Hungarian%20U-boats">U-boats</a> to attack Allied shipping rather than risk the destruction of its <a href="List%20of%20battleships%20of%20Austria-Hungary">battleships</a>, <a href="List%20of%20cruisers%20of%20Austria-Hungary">cruisers</a> and other surface vessels. In June 1918, it attempted to break the Otranto Barrage with a large naval fleet, but the attack was called off after the battleship was sunk by an Italian torpedo boat on 10 June.
Five months later, with the Austro-Hungarian Empire facing collapse and defeat in the war, the Empire decided to transfer most of its navy to the newly declared <a href="State%20of%20Slovenes%2C%20Croats%20and%20Serbs">State of Slovenes, Croats and Serbs</a> on 31 October, effectively bringing the k.u.k. Kriegsmarine to an end. Three days later, the Empire's military authorities signed the <a href="Armistice%20of%20Villa%20Giusti">Armistice of Villa Giusti</a>, pulling the rapidly disintegrating empire out of the war. With the signing of the <a href="Treaty%20of%20Saint-Germain-en-Laye%20%281919%29">Treaty of Saint-Germain-en-Laye</a> and the <a href="Treaty%20of%20Trianon">Treaty of Trianon</a>, Austria and Hungary became landlocked, and the Empire's most important ports of <a href="Trieste">Trieste</a>, <a href="Pula">Pola</a>, <a href="Rijeka">Fiume</a> and <a href="Dubrovnik">Ragusa</a> became part of <a href="Italy">Italy</a> and Yugoslavia. The k.u.k. Kriegsmarine's main ships were turned over to the Allies, who scrapped most of them in the 1920s during the era of naval disarmament.
History.
Origins.
The k.u.k. Kriegsmarine was not formally established until the 18th century, but its origins can be traced back to 1382, with the incorporation of Trieste into the <a href="Duchy%20of%20Austria">Duchy of Austria</a>. During the 13th and 14th centuries, Trieste became a maritime trade rival to the <a href="Republic%20of%20Venice">Republic of Venice</a>, which occupied the Adriatic port city for intermittent periods between 1283 and 1372. Under the terms of the <a href="Treaty%20of%20Turin%20%281381%29">Peace of Turin</a> in 1381, Venice renounced its claim to Trieste and the leading citizens of Trieste petitioned <a href="Leopold%20III%2C%20Duke%20of%20Austria">Leopold III, Duke of Austria</a>, to make the port part of his domains. The agreement incorporating Trieste into the Duchy of Austria was signed at the <a href="Schlossberg%20%28Graz%29">castle of Graz</a> on 30 September 1382.
While Austria had a port with the incorporation of Trieste, the city was granted a large degree of autonomy and successive Dukes of Austria paid little attention to the port or the idea of deploying a navy to protect it. Until the end of the 18th century, there were only limited attempts to establish an Austrian navy. During the <a href="Thirty%20Years%20War">Thirty Years War</a>, <a href="Generalissimo">Generalissimo</a> <a href="Albrecht%20von%20Wallenstein">Albrecht von Wallenstein</a> was awarded the Duchies of <a href="Duchy%20of%20Mecklenburg-Schwerin">Mecklenburg-Schwerin</a> and <a href="Mecklenburg-G%C3%BCstrow">Mecklenburg-Güstrow</a> as well as given the title "Admiral of the North and Baltic Seas" by <a href="Holy%20Roman%20Emperor">Holy Roman Emperor</a> <a href="Ferdinand%20II%2C%20Holy%20Roman%20Emperor">Ferdinand II</a> in 1628 after scoring several military victories against <a href="Denmark%E2%80%93Norway">Denmark–Norway</a> in northern Germany. However, Wallenstein failed to capture <a href="Stralsund">Stralsund</a>, which resisted the <a href="Capitulation%20of%20Franzburg">Capitulation of Franzburg</a> and the <a href="Battle%20of%20Stralsund%20%281628%29">subsequent siege</a> with assistance of Danish, Scottish and <a href="Sweden">Swedish</a> troops, a blow that denied him access to the Baltic and the chance of challenging the naval power of the <a href="Scandinavia">Scandinavia</a>n kingdoms and of the <a href="Netherlands">Netherlands</a>. Wallenstein's assassination at the hands of his own officers in 1634 prevented the development of any Austrian navy in either the <a href="North%20Sea">North</a> or <a href="Baltic%20Sea">Baltic Sea</a>s.
The next incursion Austria took into naval affairs occurred on the <a href="Danube">Danube</a> River rather than at sea. During the <a href="Great%20Turkish%20War">Great Turkish War</a>, <a href="Prince%20Eugene%20of%20Savoy">Prince Eugene of Savoy</a> employed a small flotilla of ships along the Danube to fight the Ottoman Empire, a practice which the <a href="House%20of%20Habsburg">House of Habsburg</a> had employed previously during the 16th and 17th centuries to fight during <a href="Ottoman%E2%80%93Habsburg%20wars">Austria's numerous wars with the Ottomans</a>. These river flotillas were largely manned by crews who came from Austria's coastal ports, and played a significant role in transporting troops across the Danube as well as denying Turkish control over the strategically important river.
Austria remained without a proper seagoing navy, however, even after the need for one became apparent with the <a href="French%20Navy">French Navy</a> bombardment of the port of Trieste during the <a href="War%20of%20Spanish%20Succession">War of Spanish Succession</a>. Lacking any sea power, Austria was unable to protect its coastal cities or project power into the Adriatic or Mediterranean Seas. The war ended with the treaties of <a href="Treaty%20of%20Utrecht">Utrecht</a>, <a href="Treaty%20of%20Rastatt">Rastatt</a>, and <a href="Treaty%20of%20Baden%20%281714%29">Baden</a>. Under the terms of the Treaty of Rastatt, Austria gained the <a href="Spanish%20Netherlands">Spanish Netherlands</a>, the <a href="Kingdom%20of%20Naples">Kingdom of Naples</a>, the <a href="Kingdom%20of%20Sicily">Kingdom of Sicily</a>, the <a href="Kingdom%20of%20Sardinia">Kingdom of Sardinia</a>, and the <a href="Duchy%20of%20Milan">Duchy of Milan</a>. While Austria's control over Sardinia and Naples was cut short by their loss to Spain in 1734 during the <a href="War%20of%20Polish%20Succession">War of Polish Succession</a>, these territories as well as the new <a href="Austrian%20Netherlands">Austrian Netherlands</a> gave Austria greater access to the sea than ever before.
Following the War of Spanish Succession, Austria once again developed interest in establishing a proper navy in order to protect its now numerous coastal possessions. This coincided with the majority of European nations' growing interest in <a href="mercantilism">mercantilism</a>, the founding and development of <a href="colonies">colonies</a>, and the chartering of overseas trading companies during the early 18th century. Austria's largest obstacle in engaging in overseas trade and naval enterprises however lay in the country's geography. Despite Austria having a lengthy coastline along the Adriatic Sea, the major ports it possessed along its main coastline were isolated from <a href="Vienna">Vienna</a> by the large <a href="Austrian%20Alps">Austrian Alps</a>. Furthermore, there were no major rivers linking Austria's Adriatic ports to the interior of the country. Austria also enjoyed three major navigable rivers which flowed through the country, the <a href="Elbe">Elbe</a>, the <a href="Oder">Oder</a>, and the Danube. However, the Elbe and the Oder flowed through the <a href="Kingdom%20of%20Prussia">Kingdom of Prussia</a> before emptying into the North and Baltic Sea respectively, while the mouth of the Danube lay within the territory of the Ottoman Empire. Both of these nations remained major rivals of Austria throughout the 18th century, preventing the Austrians from using its major rivers to gain access to the sea.
The Ostend Company.
Following the War of Spanish Succession, Austria's greatest outlet to the sea lay in the newly acquired Austrian Netherlands. While non-contiguous with the rest of Austria, the Austrian Netherlands lay within the boundaries of the Habsburg-dominated <a href="Holy%20Roman%20Empire">Holy Roman Empire</a>. The territory also possessed numerous ports with easy access to the <a href="Atlantic%20Ocean">Atlantic Ocean</a>, such as <a href="Ghent">Ghent</a>, <a href="Antwerp">Antwerp</a>, <a href="Bruges">Bruges</a> and <a href="Ostend">Ostend</a>. However, the economy of the Austrian Netherlands was very disconnected from the rest of Austria, and most Habsburg rulers paid little attention to the province. Even Prince Eugene of Savoy, upon being appointed Governor-General of the Austrian Netherlands in June 1716, chose to remain in Vienna and direct policy through his chosen representative, <a href="Hercule-Louis%20Turinetti%2C%20marquis%20of%20Pri%C3%A9">Hercule-Louis Turinetti, marquis of Prié</a>.
The success of the <a href="Dutch%20East%20India%20Company">Dutch</a>, <a href="East%20India%20Company">British</a> and <a href="French%20East%20India%20Company">French</a> East India Companies throughout the 17th and early 18th centuries however led the merchants and shipowners of Ostend to want to establish direct commercial relations with the <a href="East%20Indies">East Indies</a>. In December 1722, Charles VI granted a 30-year charter to the <a href="Ostend%20Company">Ostend Company</a> to conduct trade with the East and <a href="West%20Indies">West Indies</a>, as well as <a href="Africa">Africa</a>. The Ostend Company proved to be immensely profitable, and between 1724 and 1732, 21 company vessels were sent out to conduct trade in the <a href="Caribbean">Caribbean</a>, Africa, and especially <a href="Asia">Asia</a>. The most profitable voyages of the Ostend Company were to <a href="Guangzhou">Canton</a>, as rising tea prices resulted in high profits for ships conducting trade with <a href="China">China</a>. Between 1719 and 1728, the Ostend Company transported 7 million pounds of tea from <a href="Qing%20dynasty">China</a>, roughly half of the total amount brought to western Europe at the time, placing the company on par in the tea trade with the <a href="East%20India%20Company">East India Company</a>. The Ostend Company proved to be short lived however, as Charles VI suspended the charter of the company due to British diplomatic requests following the <a href="Treaty%20of%20Vienna%20%281731%29">Treaty of Vienna</a>, with the company ceasing operations in 1731.
Charles VI and Maria Theresa.
Believing that "Navigation and commerce are the foremost pillars of the state," Holy Roman Emperor <a href="Charles%20VI%2C%20Holy%20Roman%20Emperor">Charles VI</a> engaged in other projects beyond the establishment of the Ostend Company in order to increase Austria's merchant marine and establish a proper navy to protect it. This included constructing a new road through the <a href="Semmering%20Pass">Semmering Pass</a> in order to link Vienna to Trieste, and declaring Trieste and <a href="Fiume">Fiume</a> <a href="free%20port">free port</a>s in 1719. In order to help protect Austrian merchants from piracy in the Adriatic and Mediterranean, Charles VI also purchased the three-decker 80-gun <a href="third%20rate">third rate</a> <a href="ship%20of%20the%20line">ship of the line</a> <a href="HMS%20Cumberland%20%281695%29">"Cumberland"</a> from the United Kingdom in 1720. The ship was renamed "San Carlos" and stationed out of <a href="Naples">Naples</a>.
On the Adriatic, Charles VI constructed even more ships, usually employing Italian and Spanish officers to man them. This Adriatic fleet consisted of three ships of the line, one frigate, and several <a href="galleys">galleys</a>. In total, this Adriatic fleet had 500 guns and a crew of 8,000 men. Following the end of the Ostend Company however, a committee was set up in 1738 by the Emperor to examine the status of Austria's Adriatic fleet. Its report concluded that the fleet "had little usefulness, caused great expense, and stood in danger of being defeated in case of attack". This report eventually led to Charles VI scrapping his Adriatic fleet and transferring most of officers and crew members to Austria's Danube Flotilla.
Upon the death of Charles VI on 19 October 1740, <a href="Electorate%20of%20Saxony">Saxony</a>, <a href="Kingdom%20of%20Prussia">Prussia</a>, <a href="Electorate%20of%20Bavaria">Bavaria</a>, and <a href="Kingdom%20of%20France">France</a> all repudiated the Pragmatic Sanction of 1713 which had paved the way for Charles' daughter <a href="Maria%20Theresa">Maria Theresa</a> to succeed him. <a href="Frederick%20II%20of%20Prussia">Frederick II of Prussia</a> almost immediately invaded Austria in December 1740 and took the affluent Habsburg province of <a href="Silesia">Silesia</a> in the seven-year conflict known as the <a href="War%20of%20the%20Austrian%20Succession">War of the Austrian Succession</a>. This conflict proved to be primarily a land-based war for Austria, which led to naval affairs being neglected by the newly crowned Maria Theresa, who spent the entirety of the war preoccupied with securing her inheritance of the throne of Austria as opposed to rebuilding her father's former fleet in the Adriatic.
By the time the <a href="Seven%20Years%27%20War">Seven Years' War</a> began in 1756, Austria still lacked a proper navy. Enemy <a href="Piracy">pirates</a> and <a href="privateer">privateer</a>s, as well as <a href="Barbary%20corsairs">Barbary corsairs</a> severely hampered Austria's merchant marine, to the point that most of Austria's sea trade had to be conducted in foreign ships. The lack of any naval force to protect Austria's shipping led <a href="Count%20Kaunitz">Count Kaunitz</a> to push for the creation of a small force of <a href="frigates">frigates</a> to protect the Adriatic Sea. However, the Seven Years' War forced Vienna to pay much more attention to Austria's land border with Prussia and its coastline along the Adriatic Sea, preventing Kaunitz's program from achieving success.
In 1775, another attempt to formulate an overseas trading company was undertaken with the establishment of the <a href="Austrian%20East%20India%20Company">Austrian East India Company</a>. Headed by <a href="William%20Bolts">William Bolts</a>, the company's first voyage to India began on 24 September 1776 with Bolts sailing aboard the <a href="Indiaman">Indiaman</a> "Giuseppe e Teresa" from <a href="Livorno">Livorno</a> in the <a href="Grand%20Duchy%20of%20Tuscany">Grand Duchy of Tuscany</a>, which was ruled by Maria Theresa's son <a href="Leopold%20II%2C%20Holy%20Roman%20Emperor">Leopold</a>. Bolts was also granted a 10-year charter to trade under the flag of the Holy Roman Empire with Persia, India, China and Africa.
The Austrian East India Company marked the <a href="Austrian%20colonial%20policy">first attempt by Austria to establish overseas colonies</a>. Within the next two years, Bolts established <a href="Factory%20%28trading%20post%29">factories</a> on the <a href="Malabar%20Coast">Malabar Coast</a>, on the southeastern African coast at <a href="Maputo%20Bay">Delagoa Bay</a>, and at the <a href="Nicobar%20Islands">Nicobar Islands</a>. These ventures ultimately failed however due to pressure from other colonial powers such as Portugal and Denmark-Norway, both of which forcefully evicted Bolts and his colonists from Africa and the Bay of Bengal respectively. Furthermore, the Austrian government did not wish to provoke other foreign powers after having to fight two major continental wars in the span of just 20 years. Vienna was also unwilling to lend much monetary support to either the company or towards the creation of a navy sufficiently large enough to protect its interests. This was partially because the Austrian government expected the ports of Trieste and Fiume to bear the cost of constructing and maintaining a fleet.
Establishment of the Austrian Navy.
The Austrian Navy was finally established in 1786, with <a href="Joseph%20II%2C%20Holy%20Roman%20Emperor">Emperor Joseph II</a> purchasing two <a href="Cutter%20%28boat%29">cutters</a> in Ostend, each armed with 20 guns, and sending them to Trieste. Joseph II also introduced Austria's <a href="Naval%20Ensign">Naval Ensign</a>, which consisted of a red-white-red standard with the crown of the <a href="Archduchy%20of%20Austria">Archduchy of Austria</a> on the left. Prior to this, Austrian ships flew the yellow and black <a href="flag%20of%20the%20Habsburg%20Monarchy">flag of the Habsburg Monarchy</a>. Joseph II's "Marineflagge" remained the naval ensign of Austria, and later Austria-Hungary, until the middle of World War I.
The onset of the <a href="French%20Revolution">French Revolution</a> in 1789 and the subsequent <a href="French%20Revolutionary%20Wars">French Revolutionary Wars</a> greatly changed the political face of Europe and resulted in the largest expansion of the Austrian Navy up to that point in time. Under Joseph II's successor, <a href="Leopold%20II%2C%20Holy%20Roman%20Emperor">Leopold II</a>, the Austrian Navy was formally located out of the port of Trieste. In 1797 with the <a href="Treaty%20of%20Campo%20Formio">Treaty of Campo Formio</a> between France and Austria which ended the <a href="War%20of%20the%20First%20Coalition">War of the First Coalition</a>, Austria ceded to France the Austrian Netherlands and certain islands in the Mediterranean, including <a href="Corfu">Corfu</a> and some Venetian-held islands in the Adriatic. The Republic of Venice and its territories were divided between the two states, and Austria received the city of <a href="Venice">Venice</a> along with <a href="Istria">Istria</a> and <a href="Dalmatia">Dalmatia</a>. Venice's naval forces and facilities were also handed over to Austria and became the basis of the formation of the future Austrian Navy.
The Treaty of Campo Formio resulted in Austria becoming the largest, and indeed the only, naval power in the Adriatic. Prior to the incorporation of the remnants of the <a href="Venetian%20navy">Venetian navy</a>, the Austrian Navy only consisted of the two cutters purchased in 1786, as well as several armed merchant vessels and gunboats. While Venice had suffered under French occupation, and the ships Austria acquired from the city's annexation allowed the Austrian Navy to grow to some 37 vessels by the start of the <a href="War%20of%20the%20Second%20Coalition">War of the Second Coalition</a> in 1799. These ships mostly consisted of small coastal craft, with some 111 guns and 787 crew members between them. This still remained a very small naval force, which with an average of just three guns and 21 crew members per ship, was largely unable to project power outside of the Adriatic or protect Austrian shipping in the Mediterranean. When the <a href="Imperial%20and%20Royal%20Army%20during%20the%20Napoleonic%20Wars">Austrian Army</a> took <a href="Ancona">Ancona</a> in 1799, three former Venetian ships of the line, "Laharpe", "Stengel" and "Beyrand", were seized by the Austrians. Despite having 74 guns per-ship, far more than any other vessels in the Adriatic, the Austrian government chose to sell the ships for breaking rather than incorporate them into the Navy.
At the end of the 18th century, several new regulations were also imposed regarding naval activity. These included instructing officers to refrain from excessive shouting when giving sailing commands, directing the captains of each ship in the navy not to conduct business transactions on their own behalf, and ordering surgeons to <a href="Fumigation">fumigate</a> their ships several times a day in order to prevent the outbreak of any disease. The most notable regulation imposed directed naval officers to learn German. At the time, most Austrian naval officers were Italian or Spanish, and Italian remained the main language of the officer corps until 1848. This policy change however reflected Austria's desire to re-order its multi-ethnic Empire more towards the <a href="List%20of%20states%20in%20the%20Holy%20Roman%20Empire">German states of the Holy Roman Empire</a>.
The Napoleonic Wars.
On 17 March 1802, <a href="Archduke%20Charles%2C%20Duke%20of%20Teschen">Archduke Charles of Austria</a>, acting in his role as "Inspector General of the Navy" ordered the formation of Imperial and Royal Naval Cadet School in <a href="Venice">Venice</a>, (German: "k.u.k. Marine-Kadettenschule"). This school eventually moved to <a href="Trieste">Trieste</a> in 1848 and changed its name to the "Imperial and Royal Naval Academy" (German: "k.u.k. Marine-Akademie").
Austria again fought against France during the <a href="War%20of%20the%20Second%20Coalition">Second</a> and <a href="War%20of%20the%20Third%20Coalition">Third Coalitions</a>, when after meeting a crushing defeat at <a href="Battle%20of%20Austerlitz">Austerlitz</a>, Holy Roman Emperor <a href="Francis%20II%2C%20Holy%20Roman%20Emperor">Francis II</a> had to agree to the <a href="Treaty%20of%20Pressburg%20%281805%29">Treaty of Pressburg</a>, weakening the <a href="Austrian%20Empire">Austrian Empire</a> and reorganizing Germany under a Napoleonic imprint known as the <a href="Confederation%20of%20the%20Rhine">Confederation of the Rhine</a>.
Believing his position as Holy Roman Emperor to be untenable, Francis abdicated the throne of the Holy Roman Empire on 6 August 1806, and <a href="Dissolution%20of%20the%20Holy%20Roman%20Empire">declared the Holy Roman Empire to be dissolved</a> in the same declaration. This was a political move to impair the legitimacy of the Confederation of the Rhine. Two years earlier, as a reaction to <a href="Napoleon">Napoleon</a> making himself an <a href="Emperor%20of%20the%20French">Emperor of the French</a>, Francis had <a href="Austrian%20Empire">raised Austria to the status of an empire</a>. Hence, after 1806, he reigned as Francis I, Emperor of Austria. This move meant that the naval forces under the banner of the Holy Roman Empire were now reconstituted as solely being a part of the Austrian Navy.
Three years later Austria again declared war on France, beginning the <a href="War%20of%20the%20Fifth%20Coalition">War of the Fifth Coalition</a>. Following Austria's defeat at the <a href="Battle%20of%20Wagram">Battle of Wagram</a>, the Empire sued for peace. The resulting <a href="Treaty%20of%20Sch%C3%B6nbrunn">Treaty of Schönbrunn</a> imposed harsh terms on Austria. Austria had to hand over the <a href="Duchy%20of%20Salzburg">Duchy of Salzburg</a> to the <a href="Kingdom%20of%20Bavaria">Kingdom of Bavaria</a> and lost its access to the <a href="Adriatic%20Sea">Adriatic Sea</a> by ceding the <a href="Austrian%20Littoral">Littoral</a> territories of <a href="Gorizia%20and%20Gradisca">Gorizia and Gradisca</a> and the <a href="Imperial%20Free%20City%20of%20Trieste">Imperial Free City of Trieste</a>, together with <a href="Duchy%20of%20Carniola">Carniola</a>, the <a href="March%20of%20Istria">March of Istria</a>, western <a href="Duchy%20of%20Carinthia">Carinthia</a> with <a href="East%20Tyrol">East Tyrol</a>, and the <a href="Kingdom%20of%20Croatia%20%28Habsburg%29">Croatia</a>n lands southwest of the river <a href="Sava">Sava</a> to the French Empire. <a href="West%20Galicia">West Galicia</a> was ceded to the <a href="Duchy%20of%20Warsaw">Duchy of Warsaw</a>, and <a href="Tarnopol">Tarnopol</a> was given to the <a href="Russian%20Empire">Russian Empire</a>. These terms eliminated Austria's coastline along the Adriatic, thus destroying the Austrian Navy, with its warships being handed over to the French to guard the newly formed the <a href="Illyrian%20provinces">Illyrian provinces</a>. Between 1809 and 1814, there was no Austrian coastline and subsequently no navy to defend it.
Modernising the Navy.
Following the <a href="Congress%20of%20Vienna">Congress of Vienna</a> and the 1815 <a href="Treaty%20of%20Paris%20%281815%29">Treaty of Paris</a>, Austria's coastline was restored. Under the conditions of the Congress of Vienna, the former Austrian Netherlands were transferred to the newly created <a href="United%20Kingdom%20of%20the%20Netherlands">United Kingdom of the Netherlands</a>, while Austria received <a href="Kingdom%20of%20Lombardy%E2%80%93Venetia">Lombardy-Venetia</a> as compensation. These territorial changes gave Austria five ships of the line, two frigates, one <a href="corvette">corvette</a>, and several smaller ships which had been left in Venice by the French during the Napoleonic Wars. The decades of warfare Austria had participated in since 1789 however had left the Empire on the verge of bankruptcy, and most of these ships were sold or abandoned for financial reasons.
By the end of the decade however, the Austrian Navy began to be rebuilt. The growth of the Austrian Navy in the years following the Congress of Vienna were largely driven by political necessities, as well economic conditions. The marriage between Archduchess <a href="Maria%20Leopoldina%20of%20Austria">Maria Leopoldina</a> and Emperor <a href="Pedro%20I%20of%20Brazil">Pedro I of Brazil</a> in 1817 marked the first time a ship from the Austrian Navy crossed the <a href="Atlantic%20Ocean">Atlantic Ocean</a> to the Americas, with the Archduchess traveling with the frigates "Augusta" and "Austria" to <a href="Rio%20de%20Janeiro">Rio de Janeiro</a>. Three years later, the frigate "Carolina" escorted Austria's ambassador to Brazil across the Atlantic, before sailing on to China, marking the first time a ship from the Austrian Navy had traveled to <a href="East%20Asia">East Asia</a>. During the 1820s and early 1830s, Austrian trade along the Danube and within the Mediterranean grew rapidly. In 1830, the Austrian Danube Steam Navigation Company was founded and in 1834, its <a href="steamship">steamship</a> "Marie Dorothee" became the first of its kind to travel the Mediterranean on a voyage between Trieste and Constantinople. In 1836, the <a href="%C3%96sterreichischer%20Lloyd">Austrian Lloyd</a> (German: "Österreichischer Lloyd") was established. While Austria's merchant marine grew throughout the 1820s and 1830s, the Austrian Navy grew alongside it in order to provide protection on the high seas.
During the <a href="Greek%20War%20of%20Independence">Greek War of Independence</a>, the Austrian Navy engaged Greek pirates who routinely attempted to attack Austrian shipping in order to help fund the Greek rebellion against Ottoman rule. During the same time period, Barbary corsairs continued to prey upon Austrian shipping in the Western Mediterranean. These two threats greatly stretched the resources of Austria's naval forces, which were still rebuilding after the Napoleonic Wars. In 1829, two Austrian corvettes, a <a href="brig">brig</a>, and a <a href="schooner">schooner</a> under Lieutenant Commander (German: "<a href="Korvettenkapit%C3%A4n">Korvettenkapitän</a>") Franz Bandiera sailed Morocco's Atlantic coast to obtain the release of an Austrian merchant ship which had been captured by pirates. While the mission resulted in the return of the ship's crew, the Moroccans refused to return the ship, resulting in the Austrian bombardment of <a href="Larache">Larache</a>. This action resulted in Morocco returning the captured Austrian ship, as well as pay damages to Vienna. The bombardment of Larache resulted in the end of North African pirates raiding Austrian shipping in the Mediterranean Sea.
By the 1830s, an attempt to modernize the Navy had begun. The Austrian government granted new funding for the construction of additional ships and the purchasing of new equipment. The most notable change which was undertaken was the incorporation of steamships, with the first such ship in the Austrian Navy, the <a href="paddle%20steamer">paddle steamer</a> "Maria Anna", being constructed in Fiume. "Maria Anna"s first trials took place in 1836. In 1837, <a href="Friedrich%20Ferdinand%20Leopold%20of%20Austria">Archduke Friedrich Leopold</a> enlisted into the Navy. The third son of Archduke Charles, a famous veteran of the Napoleonic Wars, Friedrich's decision to join the Navy greatly enhanced its prestige among the Austrian nobility and public. During his time in the Navy, Friedrich introduced many modernizing reforms, aiming to make the Austrian Navy less "Venetian" in character and more "Austrian".
Oriental Crisis of 1840.
Friedrich and the Austrian Navy had their first major military encounter during the <a href="Oriental%20Crisis%20of%201840">Oriental Crisis of 1840</a>. After his victory over the <a href="Ottoman%20Empire">Ottoman Empire</a> during the <a href="Egyptian%E2%80%93Ottoman%20War%20%281831%E2%80%9333%29">First Egyptian-Ottoman War</a>, <a href="Muhammad%20Ali%20of%20Egypt">Muhammad Ali of Egypt</a> conquered large parts of <a href="Syria%20Vilayet">Syria</a>. In 1839, the Ottomans attempted to reclaim these territories but after a decisive defeat at the <a href="Battle%20of%20Nezib">Battle of Nezib</a>, the Ottoman Empire appeared on the verge of collapse. Through the <a href="Convention%20of%20London%20%281840%29">Convention of London</a>, the United Kingdom, Austria, Prussia, and Russia intervened to save the Ottoman Empire. The Convention offered Muhammad Ali hereditary rule of Egypt while nominally remaining part of the Ottoman Empire if he withdrew from most of Syria. Muhammad Ali hesitated to accept the offer however and in September 1840 the European powers moved to engage Muhammad Ali's forces.
The British and Austrian navies subsequently blockaded the <a href="Nile%20Delta">Nile Delta</a> and bombarded <a href="Beirut">Beirut</a> on 11 September 1840. On 26 September, Friedrich, commanding the Austrian frigate "Guerriera", bombarded the port of <a href="Sidon">Sidon</a> with British support. The Austrians and British landed in the city and stormed its coastal fortifications, capturing it on 28 September. After capturing Sidon, Austria's naval squadron sailed on to <a href="Acre%2C%20Israel">Acre</a> which bombarded the city in November, destroying its coastal fortifications and silencing the city's guns. During the storming of the city, Friedrich personally led the Austro-British landing party and hoisted the Ottoman, British, and Austrian flags over the Acre's citadel upon its capture. For his leadership during the campaign, Archduke Friedrich was awarded the <a href="Military%20Order%20of%20Maria%20Theresa">"Knight of the Military Order of Maria Theresa"</a>. In 1844, Archduke Friedrich was promoted to the rank of <a href="Vice-Admiral">Vice-Admiral</a> and become Commander-in-Chief of the Navy at the age of 23, but his tenure as the head of the Austrian Navy ended just three years after his appointment when he died in Venice at the age of 26.
Revolutions of 1848.
After a successful <a href="French%20Revolution%20of%201848">revolution in France</a> in February 1848 toppled King <a href="Louis%20Philippe%20I">Louis Philippe I</a> and established a <a href="Second%20French%20Republic">Second French Republic</a>, <a href="Revolutions%20of%201848">revolutionary fervor broke out across Europe</a>. In Vienna, <a href="List%20of%20Ministers-President%20of%20Austria">Austrian Chancellor</a> <a href="Klemens%20von%20Metternich">Klemens von Metternich</a> resigned his post and leave in exile to London while Emperor <a href="Ferdinand%20I%20of%20Austria">Ferdinand I</a> was forced to abdicate the throne in favor of his nephew, Franz Joseph. Across the Austrian Empire, <a href="nationalist">nationalist</a> sentiments among Austria's various ethnic groups led to the <a href="Revolutions%20of%201848%20in%20the%20Austrian%20Empire">revolutions in Austria</a> to take several different forms. Liberal sentiments prevailed extensively among the German Austrians, which were further complicated by the <a href="German%20revolutions%20of%201848%E2%80%9349">simultaneous events in the German states</a>. The Hungarians within the Empire largely sought to establish their own independent kingdom or republic, which resulted in a <a href="Hungarian%20Revolution%20of%201848">revolution in Hungary</a>. Italians within the Austrian Empire likewise sought to unify with the other Italian-speaking states of the Italian Peninsula to form a "Kingdom of Italy".
The revolution in Vienna sparked anti-Habsburg riots in Milan and Venice. Field Marshal Joseph Radetzky was unable to defeat the <a href="Republic%20of%20San%20Marco">Venetian</a> and <a href="Five%20Days%20of%20Milan">Milanese</a> insurgents in Lombardy-Venetia, and had to order his forces to evacuate western Italy, pulling his forces back to a chain of defensive fortresses between Milan and Venice known as the <a href="Quadrilatero">Quadrilatero</a>. With <a href="Vienna%20Uprising">Vienna itself in the middle of an uprising</a> against the Habsburg Monarchy, the Austrian Empire appeared on the brink of collapse. On 23 March 1848, just one day after Radetzky was forced to retreat from Milan, The Kingdom of Sardinia declared war on the Austrian Empire, sparking the <a href="First%20Italian%20War%20of%20Independence">First Italian War of Independence</a>.
First War of Italian Independence.
Venice was at the time one of Austria's largest and most important ports, and the revolution which began there nearly led to the disintegration of the Austrian Navy. The Austrian commander of the Venetian Naval Yard was beaten to death by his own men, while the head of the city's Marine Guard was unable to provide any aid to suppress the uprising as most of the men under his command deserted. Vice-Admiral Anton von Martini, Commander-in-Chief of the Navy, attempted to put an end to the rebellion but was betrayed by his officers, the majority of whom were Venetians, and subsequently captured and held prisoner. By the end of March, the Austrian troops in Venice were forced from the city and the Austrian Navy appeared to be collapsing as many of the Austrian sailors and officers were of Italian descent. Fearing mutinies, Austrian officers ultimately relieved these Italian sailors of their duty and permitted them to return home. While this action left the Navy drastically undermanned, it prevented any wide-scale disintegration within the Navy which the Austrian Army had repeatedly suffered from in Italy.
The loss of so many Italian crew members and officers meant that the remaining ships which did not fall into rebel hands in Venice were lacking many crews. Out of roughly 5,000 men who were members of the Austrian Navy prior to the revolution, only 72 officers and 665 sailors remained. Further complicating matters for the Austrian Navy was the loss of Venice's naval dockyards, warehouses, its arsenal, as well as three corvettes and several smaller vessels to the Venetian rebels. The loss of Vice-Admiral Martini was also a blow to Austrians, as the Navy had gone through no less than four Commanders-in-Chief within three months of the death of Archduke Friedrich in late 1847. Martini's capture left the Navy without a commander for the fifth time in as many months. In the aftermath of the loss of Venice, the Austrian Navy reorganized itself under the temporary command of General Count <a href="Franz%20Gyulai">Franz Gyulai</a>. Gyulai recalled every Austrian ship in the Mediterranean, the Adriatic, and in the Levant. Due to Trieste's close location to the parts of Italy revolting against Austrian rule at the time, Gyulai also chose the small port of Pola as the new base for the Austrian Navy. This marked the first time the city had been used as an Austrian naval base, and from 1848 onwards the city continued to serve as a base for Austrian warships until the end of World War I. In late April, this fleet began a blockade of Venice in order to assist Austria's army currently fighting the Italian nationalists who had seized the city.
Meanwhile, fortunes continued to fade for the Austrians. The <a href="Papal%20States">Papal States</a> and the <a href="Kingdom%20of%20the%20Two%20Sicilies">Kingdom of the Two Sicilies</a> both joined the war on the side of Sardinia, the later sending a naval force into the Adriatic in cooperation with Sardinia to help seize Venice. This Italian fleet consisted of five frigates and several smaller vessels acquired by the Italian nationalists in Venice. Against this force, the Austrian Navy counted three frigates of 44 to 50 guns, two corvettes of 18 and 20 guns, eight brigs of six to 16 guns, 34 gunboats with three guns each, and two steamers of two guns. Despite its relatively large size for navies in the Adriatic, the Austrian Navy lacked experience against the combined Italian forces and Gyulai decided to withdraw his ships to Pola. After the Austrians moved back to Trieste due to the fact that Pola's small and undeveloped dockyards could not handle the size of the Austrian fleet, a stalemate ensued in the Adriatic. The Austrian fleet was too small to go on the offensive against the Italians, while the Italian naval commander, Rear Admiral <a href="Giovanbattista%20Albini">Giovanbattista Albini</a>, was under orders not to attack the port of Trieste as its location within the <a href="German%20Confederation">German Confederation</a> may draw in other powers in <a href="central%20Europe">central Europe</a> against Sardinia. Austrian efforts to purchase additional warships from the United Kingdom, Russia, the Ottoman Empire, and from Egypt, all ended in failure as the funds to purchase the ships were instead used to fight Austria's many land battles with Hungarian and Italian nationalists, as well as the war with Sardinia. Early experimentation on the use of a self-propelled explosive device—forerunner to the torpedo—to attack the Italian ships also failure due to the technological constraints of the time. Additional proposals to break the Italian fleet by using <a href="fire%20ship">fire ship</a>s was rejected as an "inhumane" way of fighting.
The stalemate in the Adriatic came to an end as the Papal States and the Kingdom of the Two Sicilies pulled out of the war. Austrian reinforcements bolstered Radetzky's forces in the Italian peninsula and following the <a href="Battle%20of%20Custoza%20%281848%29">Battle of Custoza</a> in July 1848, the tide of the war turned in Austria's favor. On 9 August, an armistice was signed between Sardinia and Austria, and a month later, Admiral Martini was released in a prisoner exchange and returned as head of the Navy. While Martini unsuccessfully lobbied for the purchase of new steam ships to re-establish a blockade of Venice, Sardinia resumed the war with Austria on 12 March 1849. This led to the disastrous Sardinian defeat at the <a href="Battle%20of%20Novara%20%281849%29">Battle of Novara</a> ten days later. The decisive defeat forced King <a href="Charles%20Albert%20of%20Sardinia">Charles Albert of Sardinia</a> to abdicate the throne of Sardinia in favor of his son Victor Emmanuel II and brought the First War of Italian Independence to an end in August 1849. Venice was the last Italian nationalist holdout to fall on 27 August 1849.
Aftermath and effects on the Navy.
The Revolutions of 1848 marked a turning point in the history of the Austrian Navy. Up until that time, the Navy had been dominated by the Italian language, customs, and traditions. Prior to the revolution, the Austrian Navy was mostly made up of Italian crew members, the Italian language was the primary language, and even Italian ship names were used over German ones, such as "Lipsia" rather than "Leipzig". Indeed, in the years before 1848, the Navy was largely considered to be a "local affair of Venice". In the years after 1848, most of the navy's officers corps hailed from the German-speaking parts of the Empire, while most of the sailors came from Istria and the Dalmatian Coast, leading to Croats, Germans, and even Hungarians to begin to be represented among the ranks of the Austrian Navy.
After retaking Venice, the Austrians acquired several warships which were under construction or already seaworthy. Most of these ships were added to the strength of the Austrian Navy, increasing the size and strength of the Navy considerably by the year 1850. In Venice the naval shipyard was retained. Here the Austrian screw-driven gunboat "Kerka" (crew: 100) was launched in 1860 (in service until 1908).
In the final months of the blockade of Venice, the Danish-born was appointed Commander-in-Chief of the Austrian Navy. Emperor Franz Joseph I selected Dahlerup due to his desire to replace Italian influence within the Navy. Dahlerup introduced many personal reforms, such as reorganizing the command structure of the Navy, establishing new service regulations, and setting up a school for naval officers. He also began the process of replacing Italian with German as the spoken de facto language of the Austrian Navy. However, Dahlerup's command style clashed heavily with the prevailing culture within the Austrian Navy and he resigned after just over two years.
The Ferdinand Max era.
After a two-year interim period in which Lieutenant General Count <a href="Franz%20Wimpffen">Franz Wimpffen</a> commanded the Navy, in September 1854 Emperor Franz Joseph I promoted his younger brother, <a href="Maximilian%20I%20of%20Mexico">Archduke Ferdinand Maximilian</a> (commonly referred to as Ferdinand Max), to the rank of Rear Admiral and named him Commander-in-Chief of the Austrian Navy. At the age of 22, Ferdinand Max became the youngest "Oberkommandant" in the history of the Austrian Navy, being a year younger than when Archduke Friedrich of Austria assumed command of the navy ten years earlier.
Despite his age, the fact that he had only been in the Navy for four years, and his lack of experience in battle or command on the high seas, Ferdinand Max proved to be among the most effective and successful commanders of the Austrian Navy in history. He was described by Lawrence Sondhaus in his book "The Habsburg Empire and the Sea: Austrian Naval Policy, 1797–1866" as "the most gifted leader the navy had ever had, or ever would have". Anthony Sokol describes Ferdinand Max in his book "The Imperial and Royal Austro-Hungarian Navy" as "one of the most talented of the Habsburg princes...He used his prestige, youthful enthusiasm, and love of the Service to promote it in every way possible."
Ferdinand Max worked hard to separate the Austrian Navy from its dependence upon the Austrian Army, which had nominal control over its affairs. On 14 January 1862, Franz Joseph I agreed to establish the Ministry of Marine, which oversaw the affairs of both the Austrian Navy, and the Austrian merchant marine, and named Count <a href="Matthais%20von%20Wickenburg">Matthais von Wickenburg</a> its head. Under this new system, Ferdinand Max continued to be the "Oberkommandant", but he was no longer responsible for the political management of the fleet. In addition to obtaining support for the creation of Ministry of Marine, Ferdinand Max was given great freedom by the Emperor to manage the navy as he saw fit, especially with respect to the construction and acquisition of new warships.
Development of the Austrian Navy: 1854–1860.
Ferdinand Max immediately went to work expanding the Austrian Navy. Fears of over-dependence upon foreign shipyards to supply Austrian warships enabled him to convince his brother to authorize the construction of a new drydock at <a href="Pula">Pola</a>, and the expansion of existing shipyards in Trieste. Furthermore, Ferdinand Max initiated an ambitious construction program in the ports of Pola, Trieste, and Venice, the largest the Adriatic had seen since the Napoleonic Wars. Pola in particular saw a considerable amount of attention as its natural harbor and strategic location along the Adriatic coastline of Austria enabled ships docked there to provide protection for Trieste as well as the Dalmatian Coast. While it had been used as a base for the Navy during the Revolutions of 1848, the small dockyards and port facilities, coupled with surrounding swampland had hindered its development. In addition to Pola's new drydock, Ferdinand Max had the swamps drained and constructed a new arsenal for the city.
By 1855, a screw-powered ship-of-the-line was under construction in Pola after failed bids to construct the ship with British and American shipbuilding firms, while two screw-frigates and two screw-corvettes were being built in Trieste and Venice respectively. Within a year of Ferdinand Max's promotion to "Oberkommandant", the Austrian Navy consisted of four frigates, four corvettes, and two paddle steamers in active service in the Mediterranean Sea. Ferdinand Max followed up on this progress however by purchasing the steam frigate from the United Kingdom in 1856. Her design was used for the construction of future ships of the Navy, and marked the beginning of Austria's modern shipbuilding industry. From 1856 onward, a majority of Austria's ships were constructed by domestic shipyards. Ferdinand Max's next construction project was the last Austrian ship-of-the-line, . She was commissioned into the Austrian Navy in 1859 after being constructed at the newly built <a href="Pola%20Navy%20Yard">Pola Navy Yard</a> between 1855 and 1858.
As a result of these construction projects, the Austrian Navy grew to its largest size since the War of Austrian Succession over 100 years prior. Despite these efforts however, the Navy was still considerably smaller than its French, British, or Sardinian counterparts. Indeed, the Austrian Navy was still attempting to catch up to the technological developments which had emerged during the first half of the 19th century with respect to steam power, when the emergence of the French iron-platted floating battery "Dévastation" gained international attention following its use during the <a href="Crimean%20War">Crimean War</a> in October 1855. "Dévastation" signalled the beginning of the emergence of ironclad warships over the course of the next decade.
Indeed, the French Navy's technological and numerical edge proved to be decisive in driving the Austrian Navy to port shortly after the outbreak of the <a href="Second%20War%20of%20Italian%20Independence">Second War of Italian Independence</a>. After the failure of the First Italian War of Independence, Sardinia began the search for potential allies. Sardinian Prime Minister <a href="Camillo%20Benso%2C%20Count%20of%20Cavour">Camillo Benso, Count of Cavour</a>, found <a href="French%20Emperor">French Emperor</a> <a href="Napoleon%20III">Napoleon III</a> supportive of an alliance with Sardinia following the Crimean War, in which France and Sardinia were allies against the Russian Empire. After the <a href="Plombi%C3%A8res%20Agreement">Plombières Agreement</a> of 1858, Napoleon III and Cavour signed a secret treaty of alliance against Austria whereby France would assist Sardinia in return for <a href="Nice">Nice</a> and <a href="Savoy">Savoy</a> being ceded to France. During the first half of 1859, the Franco-Sardinian forces quickly defeated the Austrians on land, culminating in the <a href="Battle%20of%20Solferino">Battle of Solferino</a>, while the French Navy blockaded the Adriatic Sea and forced the Austrian Navy to remain in port, preventing its use for the duration of the war. After the defeat at Solferino, Austria ceded most of Lombardy and the city of Milan to France under the <a href="Treaty%20of%20Z%C3%BCrich">Treaty of Zürich</a>, who transferred it to Sardinia in exchange for Savoy and Nice.
In response to Austria's quick defeat during the Second War of Italian Independence, Ferdinand Max proposed an even larger naval construction program than the one he had initiated upon his appointment as "Oberkommandant". This fleet would be large enough not only to show the Austrian flag around the world, but also to protect its merchant marine as well as thwart any Adriatic ambitions from the growing Kingdom of Sardinia. However, constitutional reforms enacted in Austria after the defeat, as well as the recent introduction of <a href="ironclad">ironclad</a>s into the navies of the world, made the proposal more expensive than he had initially intended. While the Archduke had previously been given free rein over naval affairs, and had enjoyed an unprecedented allocation of new funds to complete his various expansion and modernization projects, Austria's recent military defeats and financial difficulties in the immediate aftermath of the war stalled his plans for further construction projects. Despite these obstacles, the initiation of the Italian ironclad program between 1860 and 1861, coupled with Austrian fears of an Italian invasion or seaborne landing directed against Venice, Trieste, Istria, and the Dalmatian Coast, necessitated an Austrian naval response to counter the growing strength of the Italian Regia Marina.
The Austro-Italian ironclad arms race.
After the Second War of Italian Independence, Sardinia ordered two small ironclads from France in 1860. While these ships were under construction, the Italian revolutionary <a href="Giuseppe%20Garibaldi">Giuseppe Garibaldi</a> began his campaign to conquer <a href="Southern%20Italy">Southern Italy</a> in the name of the Kingdom of Sardinia. He quickly <a href="Expedition%20of%20the%20Thousand">toppled</a> the <a href="Kingdom%20of%20the%20Two%20Sicilies">Kingdom of the Two Sicilies</a>, the largest state in the region in a matter of months. On 17 March 1861, <a href="Victor%20Emmanuel%20II%20of%20Italy">Victor Emmanuel II</a> was proclaimed <a href="King%20of%20Italy">King of Italy</a>. With the <a href="unification%20of%20Italy">unification of Italy</a>, the various navies of the former Italian states were merged into a single military force, named the <a href="Regia%20Marina">Regia Marina</a> (Royal Navy). By the time the two s had been commissioned, they formed the first <a href="Ironclad%20warship%23Broadside%20ironclads">broadside ironclads</a> of the Italian Regia Marina.
Following up on these ships, Italy launched a substantial program to bolster the strength of the Regia Marina. The Italians believed that building a strong navy would play a crucial role in making the recently unified kingdom a <a href="Great%20Power">Great Power</a>. These actions captured the attention of the <a href="Austrian%20Empire">Austrian Empire</a>, which viewed Italy with great suspicion and worry, as <a href="Italian%20irredentism">irredentist</a> claims by Italian <a href="Nationalism">nationalists</a> were directed at key Austrian territories such as <a href="Venice">Venice</a>, <a href="Trentino">Trentino</a>, and <a href="Trieste">Trieste</a>. In response to the growing strength of the Regia Marina, the Imperial Austrian Navy subsequently ordered two ironclads in 1860. In the years immediately after the unification of Italy, Austria and Italy engaged in a naval <a href="arms%20race">arms race</a> centered upon the <a href="Austro-Italian%20ironclad%20arms%20race">construction and acquisition of ironclads</a>. This arms race between the two nations continued for the rest of Ferdinand Max's tenure as "Oberkommandant".
Novara Expedition.
Archduke Ferdinand Maximilian also initiated a large-scale scientific expedition (1857–1859) during which the <a href="frigate">frigate</a> became the first Austrian warship to <a href="circumnavigation">circumnavigate</a> the globe. The journey lasted 2 years and 3 months and was accomplished under the command of Kommodore <a href="Bernhard%20von%20W%C3%BCllerstorf-Urbair">Bernhard von Wüllerstorf-Urbair</a>, with 345 officers and crew, and 7 scientists aboard. The expedition was planned by the <a href="Imperial%20Academy%20of%20Sciences%20in%20Vienna">Imperial Academy of Sciences in Vienna</a> and aimed to gain new knowledge in the disciplines of <a href="astronomy">astronomy</a>, <a href="botany">botany</a>, <a href="zoology">zoology</a>, <a href="geology">geology</a>, <a href="oceanography">oceanography</a> and <a href="hydrography">hydrography</a>. SMS "Novara" sailed from Trieste on 30 April 1857, visiting <a href="Gibraltar">Gibraltar</a>, <a href="Madeira">Madeira</a>, <a href="Rio%20de%20Janeiro">Rio de Janeiro</a>, <a href="Cape%20Town">Cape Town</a>, <a href="%C3%8Ele%20Saint-Paul">St. Paul Island</a>, <a href="Ceylon">Ceylon</a>, <a href="Madras">Madras</a>, <a href="Nicobar%20Islands">Nicobar Islands</a>, <a href="Singapore">Singapore</a>, <a href="Jakarta">Batavia</a>, <a href="Manila">Manila</a>, <a href="Hong%20Kong">Hong Kong</a>, <a href="Shanghai">Shanghai</a>, <a href="Pohnpei">Puynipet Island</a>, <a href="Sikaiana">Stuarts</a>, <a href="Sydney">Sydney</a> (5 November 1858), <a href="Auckland">Auckland</a>, <a href="Tahiti">Tahiti</a>, <a href="Valparaiso">Valparaiso</a> and <a href="Dubrovnik">Gravosa</a> before returning to Trieste on 30 August 1859.
In 1863 the <a href="Royal%20Navy">Royal Navy</a>'s battleship , the flagship of Admiral <a href="Charles%20Fremantle">Charles Fremantle</a>, made a courtesy visit to <a href="Pula">Pola</a>, the main port of the Austro-Hungarian Navy.
In April 1864 Archduke Ferdinand Maximilian stepped down as Commander-in-Chief of the Navy and accepted the throne of <a href="Second%20Mexican%20Empire">Mexico</a> from <a href="Louis%20Napoleon">Louis Napoleon</a>, becoming <a href="Maximilian%20I%20of%20Mexico">Maximilian I of Mexico</a>. He traveled from <a href="Trieste">Trieste</a> to <a href="Veracruz%2C%20Veracruz">Veracruz</a> aboard the SMS "Novara", escorted by the <a href="frigate">frigate</a>s (Austrian) and (French), and the Imperial yacht "Phantasie" led the warship procession from his palace at <a href="Miramare">Schloß Miramar</a> out to sea. When he was arrested and executed four years later, admiral <a href="Wilhelm%20von%20Tegetthoff">Wilhelm von Tegetthoff</a> was sent aboard the "Novara" to take Ferdinand Maximilian's body back to Austria.
Second Schleswig War.
The <a href="Second%20Schleswig%20War">Second Schleswig War</a> was the 1864 invasion of <a href="Schleswig-Holstein">Schleswig-Holstein</a> by Prussia and Austria. At that time, The <a href="Duchy">duchies</a> were part of the <a href="Kingdom%20of%20Denmark">Kingdom of Denmark</a>. <a href="Rear-Admiral">Rear-Admiral</a> <a href="Wilhelm%20von%20Tegetthoff">Wilhelm von Tegetthoff</a> commanded a small Austrian flotilla which traveled from the <a href="Mediterranean%20Sea">Mediterranean Sea</a> to the <a href="North%20Sea">North Sea</a>.
On May 9, 1864, Tegetthoff commanded the Austrian naval forces in the <a href="Battle%20of%20Heligoland%20%281864%29">naval action off Heligoland</a> from his flagship, the screw-driven . The action was a tactical victory for the Danish forces. It was also the last significant naval action fought by squadrons of wooden ships and the last significant naval action involving Denmark.
Third Italian War of Independence.
On 20 July 1866, near the island of <a href="Vis%20%28island%29">Vis</a> (Lissa) in the <a href="Adriatic">Adriatic</a>, the Austrian fleet, under the command of Rear-Admiral Wilhelm von Tegetthoff, made its name in the modern era at the <a href="Battle%20of%20Lissa%20%281866%29">Battle of Lissa</a> during the <a href="Third%20Italian%20War%20of%20Independence">Third Italian War of Independence</a>. The battle pitted Austrian naval forces against the <a href="Regia%20Marina">naval forces</a> of the newly created <a href="Kingdom%20of%20Italy">Kingdom of Italy</a>. It was a decisive victory for an outnumbered Austrian over a superior Italian force, and was the first major European sea battle involving ships using iron and steam, and one of the last to involve large wooden battleships and deliberate ramming.
Peacetime.
In 1873 the new sail and steam frigate (crew 480) was added to the fleet, which took part in the International Naval Review off <a href="Gru%C5%BE">Gruž</a> in 1880.
During peacetime, Austrian ships visited Asia, North America, South America, and the <a href="Pacific%20Ocean">Pacific Ocean</a>.
In 1869 Emperor Franz Joseph travelled on board the screw-driven corvette SMS "Viribus Unitis" (not to be confused with the later <a href="SMS%20Viribus%20Unitis">battleship of the same name</a>) to the opening of the <a href="Suez%20Canal">Suez Canal</a>. The ship had been named after his personal motto.
Polar Expedition.
Austro-Hungarian ships and naval personnel were also involved in <a href="Arctic">Arctic</a> exploration, discovering <a href="Franz%20Josef%20Land">Franz Josef Land</a> during an expedition which lasted from 1872 to 1874.
Led by the naval officer <a href="Karl%20Weyprecht">Karl Weyprecht</a> and the infantry officer and landscape artist <a href="Julius%20von%20Payer">Julius Payer</a>, the custom-built <a href="schooner">schooner</a> "Tegetthoff" left <a href="Troms%C3%B8">Tromsø</a> in July 1872. At the end of August, she got locked in pack-ice north of <a href="Novaya%20Zemlya">Novaya Zemlya</a> and drifted to hitherto unknown polar regions. It was on this drift when the explorers discovered an archipelago which they named after <a href="Emperor">Emperor</a> <a href="Franz%20Joseph%20I%20of%20Austria">Franz Joseph I</a>.
In May 1874 Payer decided to abandon the ice-locked ship and try to return by sledges and boats. On 14 August 1874 the expedition reached the open sea and on 3 September finally set foot on <a href="Russian%20Empire">Russia</a>n mainland.
Between the centuries.
Crete Rebellion.
In late 1896 a rebellion broke out on <a href="Ottoman%20Crete">Crete</a>, and on 21 January 1897 a <a href="Greece">Greek</a> army landed in Crete to liberate the island from the <a href="Ottoman%20Empire">Ottoman Empire</a> and unite it with <a href="Kingdom%20of%20Greece%20%28Gl%C3%BCcksburg%29">Greece</a>. The European powers, including <a href="Austria-Hungary">Austria-Hungary</a>, intervened, and proclaimed Crete an <a href="Cretan%20State">international protectorate</a>. Warships of the k.u.k. Kriegsmarine patrolled the waters off Crete in blockade of Ottoman naval forces. Crete remained in an anomalous position until finally ceded to Greece in 1913.
The Boxer Rebellion.
Austria-Hungary was part of the <a href="Eight-Nation%20Alliance">Eight-Nation Alliance</a> during the <a href="Boxer%20Rebellion">Boxer Rebellion</a> in <a href="Qing%20Empire">China</a> (1899–1901). As a member of the Allied nations, Austria sent two training ships and the cruisers , , , and and a company of marines to the North China coast in April 1900, based at the Russia concession of <a href="L%C3%BCshunkou">Port Arthur</a>.
In June they helped hold the <a href="Tianjin">Tianjin</a> railway against <a href="Righteous%20Harmony%20Society">Boxer</a> forces, and also fired upon several armed <a href="Junk%20%28ship%29">junks</a> on the <a href="Hai%20River">Hai River</a> near <a href="Tongzhou%20District%2C%20Beijing">Tong-Tcheou</a>. They also took part in the seizure of the <a href="Taku%20Forts">Taku Forts</a> commanding the approaches to Tianjin, and the boarding and capture of four Chinese <a href="destroyers">destroyers</a> by <a href="Roger%20Keyes%2C%201st%20Baron%20Keyes">Capt. Roger Keyes</a> of . In all k.u.k. forces suffered few casualties during the rebellion.
After the uprising, a cruiser was maintained permanently on the China station, and a detachment of marines was deployed at the embassy in <a href="Peking">Peking</a>.
Lieutenant <a href="Georg%20Ludwig%20von%20Trapp">Georg Ludwig von Trapp</a>, who served as a submarine commander during World War I and became famous in the musical "<a href="The%20Sound%20of%20Music">The Sound of Music</a>" after World War II, was decorated for bravery aboard during the Rebellion.
Montenegro.
During the <a href="First%20Balkan%20War">First Balkan War</a> Austria-Hungary joined <a href="German%20Empire">Germany</a>, <a href="French%20Third%20Republic">France</a>, the <a href="United%20Kingdom%20of%20Great%20Britain%20and%20Ireland">United Kingdom</a> and <a href="Kingdom%20of%20Italy">Italy</a> in blockading the seaport town of <a href="Bar%2C%20Montenegro">Bar</a> (Antivari) in the <a href="Kingdom%20of%20Montenegro">Kingdom of Montenegro</a>.
European naval arms race.
Among the many factors giving rise to World War I was the naval <a href="arms%20race">arms race</a> between the <a href="British%20Empire">British Empire</a> and <a href="Imperial%20Germany">Imperial Germany</a>. Germany enhanced her naval infrastructure, building new <a href="dry%20dock">dry dock</a>s, and enlarging the <a href="Kiel%20Canal">Kiel Canal</a> to enable larger vessels to navigate it. However, that was not the only European naval arms race. Imperial Russia too had commenced building a new modern navy following their naval defeat in the <a href="Russo-Japanese%20War">Russo-Japanese War</a>. The <a href="Austro-Hungarian">Austro-Hungarian</a> Empire and the <a href="Kingdom%20of%20Italy%20%281861%E2%80%931946%29">Kingdom of Italy</a> were in a race of their own for domination of the <a href="Adriatic%20Sea">Adriatic Sea</a>. The k.u.k. Kriegsmarine had another prominent supporter at that time in the face of the <a href="Archduke%20Franz%20Ferdinand%20of%20Austria">Archduke Franz Ferdinand</a>. Like other imperial naval enthusiasts before him, Franz Ferdinand had a keen private interest in the fleet and was an energetic campaigner for naval matters.
The dreadnought era.
In 1906 Britain completed the battleship , and it was so advanced that some argued that this rendered all previous battleships obsolete, although Britain and other countries kept pre-dreadnoughts in service.
Austria-Hungary's <a href="Naval%20architecture">naval architects</a>, aware of the inevitable dominance of all big gun dreadnought type designs, then presented their case to the "Marinesektion des Reichskriegsministeriums" (Naval Section at the War Ministry) in <a href="Vienna">Vienna</a>, which on 5 October 1908 ordered the construction of their own dreadnought, the first contract being awarded to 'Werft das <a href="Stabilimento%20Tecnico%20Triestino">Stabilimento Tecnico Triestino</a> (STT)', the naval weaponry to be provided by the <a href="%C5%A0koda%20Works">Škoda Works</a> in <a href="Plze%C5%88">Pilsen</a>. The Marine budget for 1910 was substantially enlarged to permit major refits of the existing fleet and more dreadnoughts. The battleships and were both launched by the <a href="Archduke%20Franz%20Ferdinand">Archduke Franz Ferdinand</a> at Trieste, amongst great rejoicing, on 24 June 1911, and 21 March 1912 respectively. They were followed by , and . These battleships, constructed later than many of the earlier British and German dreadnoughts, were considerably ahead in some aspects of design, especially of both the French and Italian navies, and were constructed with <a href="Marconi%20wireless">Marconi wireless</a> rooms as well as anti-aircraft armaments. It has been claimed they were the first battleships in the world equipped with torpedo launchers built into their bows.
Between 22 and 28 May 1914 "Tegetthoff", accompanied by "Viribus Unitis", made a courtesy visit to the British Mediterranean fleet in <a href="Malta">Malta</a>.
Submarine fleet.
In 1904, after allowing the navies of other countries to pioneer submarine developments, the Austro-Hungarian Navy ordered the Austrian Naval Technical Committee (MTK) to produce a submarine design. The January 1905 design developed by the MTK and other designs submitted by the public as part of a design competition were all rejected by the Navy as impracticable. They instead opted to order two submarines each of designs by <a href="Simon%20Lake">Simon Lake</a>, <a href="Friedrich%20Krupp%20Germaniawerft">Germaniawerft</a>, and <a href="John%20Philip%20Holland">John Philip Holland</a> for a competitive evaluation. The two Germaniawerft submarines comprised the "U-3" class. The Navy authorized two boats, "U-3" and "U-4", from the Germaniawerft in 1906.
The "U-3"-class was an improved version of Germaniawerft's design for the <a href="Imperial%20German%20Navy">Imperial German Navy</a>'s first U-boat, , and featured a double <a href="submarine%20hull">hull</a> with internal <a href="saddle%20tank%20%28submarine%29">saddle tank</a>s. The Germaniawerft engineers refined the design's hull shape through extensive model trials.
 and were both <a href="keel%20laying">laid down</a> on 12 March 1907 at Germaniawerft in Kiel and were <a href="launch%20%28ship%29">launch</a>ed in August and November 1908, respectively. After completion, each was towed to <a href="Pula">Pola</a> via <a href="Gibraltar">Gibraltar</a>, with "U-3" arriving in January 1909 and "U-4" arriving in April.
The was built to the same design as the <a href="United%20States%20C-class%20submarine">C-class for the US Navy</a> and was built by <a href="Robert%20Whitehead">Robert Whitehead</a>'s firm of Whitehead & Co. under license from Holland and his company, <a href="Electric%20Boat">Electric Boat</a>. Components for the first two Austrian boats were manufactured by the Electric Boat Company and assembled at Fiume, while the third boat was a speculative private venture by Whitehead that failed to find a buyer and was purchased by Austria-Hungary upon the outbreak of World War I.
The "U-5"-class boats had a single-<a href="hull%20%28watercraft%29">hull</a>ed design with a <a href="teardrop%20hull">teardrop shape</a> that bore a strong resemblance to modern nuclear submarines. The boats were just over long and <a href="displacement%20%28ship%29">displaced</a> surfaced, and submerged. The <a href="torpedo%20tube">torpedo tube</a>s featured unique, cloverleaf-shaped design <a href="hatch%20%28nautical%29">hatch</a>es that rotated on a central axis. The ships were powered by twin 6-cylinder <a href="gasoline%20engine">gasoline engine</a>s while surfaced, but suffered from inadequate ventilation which resulted in frequent intoxication of the crew. While submerged, they were propelled by twin <a href="electric%20motor">electric motor</a>s. Three boats were built in the class: U-5, U-6, and .
World War I.
Austro-Hungarian Naval Budget: 1901–1914 
After the <a href="Assassination%20of%20Archduke%20Franz%20Ferdinand%20of%20Austria">assassination</a> of <a href="Archduke%20Franz%20Ferdinand%20of%20Austria">Archduke Franz Ferdinand</a> and his wife in 1914, the Austro-Hungarian Navy honoured them with a <a href="lying%20in%20state">lying in state</a> aboard .
During the <a href="First%20World%20War">First World War</a>, the navy saw some action, but prior to the Italian entry spent much of its time in its major naval base at Pola, except for small skirmishes. Following the Italian declaration of war <a href="Fleet%20in%20being">the mere fact of its existence</a> tied up the <a href="Italian%20Navy">Italian Navy</a> and the <a href="French%20Navy">French Navy</a> in the Mediterranean for the duration of the war.
Following the declaration of war in August 1914, the French and Montenegrin forces attempted to cause havoc at <a href="Kotor">Cattaro</a>, KuK Kriegsmarine's southernmost base in the Adriatic. Throughout September, October and November 1914 the navy bombarded the <a href="Allies%20of%20World%20War%20I">Allied</a> forces resulting in a decisive defeat for the latter, and again in January 1916 in what was called the <a href="Battle%20of%20Lov%C4%87en">Battle of Lovćen</a>, which was instrumental in <a href="Montenegro">Montenegro</a> being knocked out of the war early.
On 23 May 1915, when Italy declared war on Austria-Hungary, the Austro-Hungarian navy left their harbors in <a href="Pula">Pola (today Pula, Croatia)</a>, <a href="%C5%A0ibenik">Sebenico (today Šibenik, Croatia)</a> and <a href="Kotor">Cattaro (today Kotor, Montenegro)</a> to bombard the eastern Italian coast between Venice and <a href="Barletta">Barletta</a>. Main targets were the cities of <a href="Ancona">Ancona</a>, <a href="Rimini">Rimini</a>, <a href="Vieste">Vieste</a>, <a href="Manfredonia">Manfredonia</a>, Barletta and bridges and railway tracks along the coast. Until 1917 the Austro-Hungarian fleet was as yet largely undamaged.
The presence of three Allied navies in the Mediterranean made any measures of their co-ordination and common doctrine extraordinarily difficult. The Mediterranean was divided into eleven zones, of which the British naval authorities were responsible for four, the French for four, and the Italians for three. Differing command structures, national pride and the language barrier all contributed to a lack of cohesion in the application of Allied sea power, producing a situation in which German and Austro-Hungarian U-boat attacks on shipping flourished.
Battle at Durazzo.
In December 1915 a k.u.k. Kriegsmarine cruiser squadron attempted to make a raid on the <a href="Kingdom%20of%20Serbia">Serbian</a> <a href="Serbian%20Army">troops</a> evacuating <a href="Principality%20of%20Albania">Albania</a>. After sinking a French submarine and bombarding the town of <a href="Durr%C3%ABs">Durazzo</a> the squadron ran into a minefield, sinking one destroyer and damaging another. The next day the group ran into a squadron of <a href="Royal%20Navy">British</a>, <a href="French%20Third%20Republic">French</a>, and <a href="Kingdom%20of%20Italy">Italian</a> <a href="cruiser">cruiser</a>s and <a href="destroyer">destroyer</a>s. The resulting battle left two Austro-Hungarian destroyers sunk and inflicted light damage upon another, while dealing only minor damage to the Allied cruisers and destroyers present.
A three-power conference on 28 April 1917, at <a href="Corfu">Corfu</a>, discussed a more offensive strategy in the Adriatic, but the Italians were not prepared to consider any big ship operations, considering the size of the Austro-Hungarian fleet. The British and French seemed reluctant to move alone against the Austro-Hungarians, especially if it meant a full-scale battle. But the Austrians were not inactive either, and even as the Allied conference was in session they were planning an offensive operation against the Otranto Barrage.
Battle of the Otranto Straits.
Throughout 1917 the Adriatic remained the key to the U-boat war on shipping in the Mediterranean. Cattaro, some 140 miles above the narrow Straits of Otranto, was the main U-boat base from which almost the entire threat to Mediterranean shipping came.
The <a href="Otranto%20Barrage">Otranto Barrage</a>, constructed by the Allies with up to 120 <a href="naval%20drifter">naval drifter</a>s, used to deploy and patrol submarine nets, and 30 motor launches, all equipped with depth charges, was designed to stop the passage of U-boats from Cattaro. However, this failed to do so, and from its inception in 1916, the barrage had caught only two U-boats, the Austrian and the German out of hundreds of possible passages.
However, the barrage effectively meant that the Austro-Hungarian surface fleet could not leave the <a href="Adriatic%20Sea">Adriatic Sea</a> unless it was willing to give battle to the blocking forces. This, and as the war drew on bringing supply difficulties especially coal, plus a fear of mines, limited the Austro-Hungarian navy to shelling the Italian and Serbian coastlines.
There had already been four small-scale Austro-Hungarian attacks on the barrage, on 11 March, 21 and 25 April and 5 May 1917, but none of them amounted to anything. Now greater preparations were made, with two U-boats despatched to lay mines off <a href="Brindisi">Brindisi</a> with a third patrolling the exits in case Anglo-Italian forces were drawn out during the attack. The whole operation was timed for the night of 14/15 May, which led to the biggest battle of the Austro-Hungarian navy in World War I, the Battle of the Otranto Straits.
The first Austro-Hungarian warships to strike were the two <a href="destroyer">destroyer</a>s, and . An Italian convoy of three ships, escorted by the destroyer , was approaching <a href="Vlor%C3%AB">Valona</a>, when, out of the darkness, the Austrians fell upon them. "Borea" was left sinking. Of the three merchant ships, one loaded with ammunition was hit and blown up, a second set on fire, and the third hit. The two Austrian destroyers then steamed off northward.
Meanwhile, three Austro-Hungarian <a href="cruiser">cruiser</a>s under the overall command of Captain <a href="Mikl%C3%B3s%20Horthy">Miklós Horthy</a>, , , and , had actually passed a patrol of four French destroyers north of the barrage, and thought to be friendly ships passed unchallenged. They then sailed through the barrage before turning back to attack it. Each Austrian cruiser took one-third of the line and began slowly and systematically to destroy the barrage with their guns, urging all Allies on board to abandon their ships first.
During this battle the Allies lost two destroyers, 14 <a href="Naval%20drifter">drifters</a> and one <a href="glider%20aircraft">glider</a> while the Austro-Hungarian navy suffered only minor damage ("Novara"s steam supply pipes were damaged by a shell) and few losses. The Austro-Hungarian navy returned to its bases up north in order to repair and re-supply, and the allies had to rebuild the blockade.
Cattaro Mutiny.
In February 1918 a mutiny started in the 5th Fleet stationed at the <a href="Gulf%20of%20Cattaro">Gulf of Cattaro</a> naval base. Sailors on up to 40 ships joined the mutiny over demands for better treatment and a call to end the war.
The mutiny failed to spread beyond Cattaro, and within three days a loyal naval squadron had arrived. Together with <a href="coastal%20artillery">coastal artillery</a> the squadron fired several shells into a few of the rebel's ships, and then assaulted them with <a href="k.u.k.%20Marine%20Infantry">k.u.k. Marine Infantry</a> in a short and successful skirmish. About 800 sailors were imprisoned, dozens were court-martialed, and four seamen were executed, including the leader of the uprising, Franz Rasch, a <a href="Kingdom%20of%20Bohemia">Bohemian</a>. Given the huge crews required in naval vessels of that time, this is an indication that the mutiny was limited to a minority.
Late World War I.
A second attempt to force the blockade took place in June 1918 under the command of Rear Admiral <a href="Mikl%C3%B3s%20Horthy">Horthy</a>. A surprise attack was planned, but the mission was doomed when the fleet was by chance spotted by an Italian <a href="MAS%20boat">MAS boat</a> patrol, commanded by <a href="Luigi%20Rizzo">Luigi Rizzo</a>, which had already sunk, at anchor, the 25 year-old battleship (5,785 tons) the year before. Rizzo's <a href="MAS%20boat">MAS boat</a> launched two torpedoes, hitting one of the four Austrian <a href="dreadnought">dreadnought</a>s, the , which had already slowed down due to engine problems. The element of surprise lost, Horthy broke off his attack. Huge efforts were made by the crew to save "Szent István", which had been hit below the waterline, and the dreadnought battleship "Tegetthoff" took her in tow until a tug arrived. However just after 6 a.m., the <a href="pumps">pumps</a> being unequal to the task, the ship, now listing badly, had to be abandoned. "Szent István" sank soon afterwards, taking 89 crewmen with her. The event was filmed from a sister ship.
In 1918, in order to avoid having to give the fleet to the victors, the Austrian Emperor handed down the entire Austro-Hungarian Navy and merchant fleet, with all harbours, arsenals and shore fortifications to the new <a href="State%20of%20Slovenes%2C%20Croats%20and%20Serbs">State of Slovenes, Croats and Serbs</a>. The state of SCS was proclaimed officially on 29 October 1918 but never recognized by other countries. Diplomatic notes were sent to the governments of France, the United Kingdom, Italy, the <a href="United%20States">United States</a> and Russia, to notify them that the State of SCS was not at war with any of them and that the Council had taken over the entire Austro-Hungarian fleet; no response was provided, and for all practical purposes the war went on unchanged. Austria asked for an armistice on 29 October; after a few days' negotiation and the signatures, the armistice entered into force on 4 November.
On 1 November 1918, two sailors of the Italian "<a href="Regia%20Marina">Regia Marina</a>", <a href="Raffaele%20Paolucci">Raffaele Paolucci</a> and <a href="Raffaele%20Rossetti">Raffaele Rossetti</a>, rode a primitive manned torpedo (nicknamed the "<a href="Mignatta">Mignatta</a>" or "leech") into the Austro-Hungarian naval base at Pola. Using <a href="limpet%20mine">limpet mine</a>s, they then sank the anchored "Viribus Unitis", with considerable loss of life, as well as the freighter "Wien". The French navy commandeered the new dreadnought , which it took to France and later used for target practice in the Atlantic, where it was destroyed.
Ports and locations.
The home port of the Austro-Hungarian Navy was the "Seearsenal" (naval base) at Pola (now <a href="Pula">Pula</a>, Croatia); a role it took over from Venice, where the early Austrian Navy had been based. Supplementary bases included: the busy <a href="port">port</a> of <a href="Trieste">Trieste</a> and the natural harbour of Cattaro (now <a href="Kotor">Kotor</a>, Montenegro). Both Trieste and Pola had major shipbuilding facilities. Pola's naval installations contained one of the largest floating <a href="drydock">drydock</a>s in the <a href="Mediterranean%20Sea">Mediterranean</a>. The city of Pola was also the site of the central church of the navy "Stella Maris" ("k.u.k. Marinekirche "Stella Maris""), of the Austro-Hungarian Naval Observatory and the empire's naval <a href="military%20cemetery">military cemetery</a> ("k.u.k. Marinefriedhof").
